obfuscation: ﻿ The Only Good Indian Is a Dead Indian .
original: ﻿ The Only Good Indian Is a Dead Indian.

obfuscation: This essay is a critical study of textbook about Indians in the end of the 19th century .
original: This essay is a critical study of texts about Indians in the end of the 19th century.

obfuscation: I will give account for both the positive and damaging views white people had of the original habitants of the United States .
original: I will give account for both the positive and negative views white people had of the original habitants of the United States.

obfuscation: The view point varies a set in the different texts but most of them are written in the 1880s .
original: The view point varies a lot in the different texts but most of them are written in the 1880s.

obfuscation: The about negative attitudes towards Indians are presented in the text by Walker .
original: The most negative attitudes towards Indians are presented in the text by Walker.

obfuscation: He clearly witnesses them as inferior , primitive beings and in many ways almost like animals .
original: He clearly sees them as inferior, primitive beings and in many ways almost like animals.

obfuscation: This is mainly shown by his opinion that in the conflict between white settlers and Indians , Indians are not fighting for the same honorable causes as the white , but rather because of their instincts .
original: This is mainly shown by his opinion that in the conflict between white settlers and Indians, Indians are not fighting for the same honorable reasons as the white, but rather because of their instincts.

obfuscation: '' They can not entirely subdue the savage instincts to roam at will , to defy restraint , and to indulge their lawless appetites for blood and plunder . ''
original: "They cannot entirely subdue the savage instincts to roam at will, to defy restraint, and to indulge their lawless appetites for blood and plunder."

obfuscation: ( p.1 ) `` glutted their fiendish thirst for blood and torture '' ( p.3 ) But he also thinks that they are acting out of evil and that they are deceptive enough to `` re-enact the role of full Indians '' ( p.3 ) in order to get benefits from the whites .
original: (p.1) "glutted their fiendish thirst for blood and torture" (p.3) But he also thinks that they are acting out of evil and that they are deceptive enough to "re-enact the role of good Indians" (p.3) in order to get benefits from the whites.

obfuscation: First and foremost Indians are seen as the enemies , the fiends .
original: First and foremost Indians are seen as the enemies, the fiends.

obfuscation: In the less fierce encounters with Indians they have shown to be rude and disrespectful .
original: In the less violent encounters with Indians they have shown to be rude and disrespectful.

obfuscation: Walker writes about one such meeting where a Peace Commission was sent to Sitting bullshit .
original: Walker writes about one such meeting where a Peace Commission was sent to Sitting Bull.

obfuscation: He says that the `` distinguished visitors '' were met with `` savage discourtesy '' .
original: He says that the "distinguished visitors" were met with "savage discourtesy".

obfuscation: ( p.3 ) Another , more positive view comes from Elisabeth B Custer .
original: (p.3)  Another, more positive view comes from Elisabeth B Custer.

obfuscation: She has had many close encounters with Indians and their company and shows a lot of interest in the Indian culture .
original: She has had many close encounters with Indians and their society and shows a lot of interest in the Indian culture.

obfuscation: However in her text , damaging attitudes are also revealed in the words used to name the Indians .
original: However in her text, negative attitudes are also revealed in the words used to name the Indians.

obfuscation: She calls them creatures and savages in a way that makes you understand that those are terms normally used , but they still are words that have negative and demeaning capacity .
original: She calls them creatures and savages in a way that makes you understand that those are terms normally used, but they still are words that have negative and demeaning content.

obfuscation: They reflect the attitude of whites in cosmopolitan rather than her own opinions .
original: They reflect the attitude of whites in general rather than her own opinions.

obfuscation: Her fascination is apparent when she describes the Indians clothes and appearance .
original: Her fascination is apparent when she describes the Indians clothes and appearance.

obfuscation: '' The costume was simply superb . ''
original: "The costume was simply superb."

obfuscation: ( p.23 ) `` The Indians feet are usually very minor ; sometimes their vanity induces them to put on women 's shoes .
original: (p.23) "The Indians feet are usually very small; sometimes their vanity induces them to put on women's shoes.

obfuscation: The hands are slender and marvellously soft considering their life exposure .
original: The hands are slender and marvellously soft considering their life exposure.

obfuscation: Their speech is entire of gesture , and the flexible wrist makes their movements expressive . ''
original: Their speech is full of gesture, and the flexible wrist makes their movements expressive."

obfuscation: When she describes the Indians and their means her observations are always detailed , personal and focus on the emotions of the Indians .
original: When she describes the Indians and their ways her observations are always detailed, personal and focus on the emotions of the Indians.

obfuscation: '' The Indian kiss is not demonstrative ; the lips are laid softly on the cheek and no sound is heard or motion made .
original: "The Indian kiss is not demonstrative; the lips are laid softly on the cheek and no sound is heard or motion made.

obfuscation: It was only this grave occasion that induced the chief to show such touches . ''
original: It was only this grave occasion that induced the chief to show such feelings."

obfuscation: ( p.24 ) `` No fear showed itself , but from the characteristically stolid side hate and revenge flashed out for an instant . ''
original: (p.24) "No fear showed itself, but from the characteristically stolid face hate and revenge flashed out for an instant."

obfuscation: ( p.21 ) `` the warrior understood the unusual sight of a smile from his people . ''
original: (p.21) "the warrior understood the unusual sight of a smile from his people."

obfuscation: '' The orator saw that the faces of the Indians showed signs of humor . ''
original: "The orator saw that the faces of the Indians showed signs of humor."

obfuscation: ( p.27 ) `` The prisoner dropped his head to hide the look in his eyes that he thought ill became a warrior equally brave as he really was .
original: (p.27) "The prisoner dropped his head to hide the look in his eyes that he thought ill became a warrior as brave as he really was.

obfuscation: The bitter , revengeful thoughts with witch I had entered the room were for a moment forgotten and I about wished that he might be pardoned . ''
original: The bitter, revengeful thoughts with witch I had entered the room were for a moment forgotten and I almost wished that he might be pardoned."

obfuscation: `` the suffering among the Indians were very great . ''
original: "the suffering among the Indians was very great."

obfuscation: ( p.26 ) `` The Indians all seemed a melancholy people . ''
original: (p.26) "The Indians all seemed a melancholy people."

obfuscation: ( p.31 ) These concluding quotes show that she has sympathy for the Indians .
original: (p.31) These last quotes show that she has sympathy for the Indians.

original: One par of eyes we see the Indians through are the ones of Graham.

obfuscation: His textbooks are from the 1950s but it contains an interview from 1877 .
original: His texts are from the 1950s but it contains an interview from 1877.

obfuscation: He has perspective on the conflicts between Indians and whites and he writes much more about how the Indians have been mistreated , which has become more coarse as time has gone by .
original: He has perspective on the conflicts between Indians and whites and he writes much more about how the Indians have been mistreated, which has become more common as time has gone by.

obfuscation: `` those who had already bowed their necks to the blank man 's yoke had been cheated abused and made captives de facto whatever may have been their status de jure . ''
original: "those who had already bowed their necks to the white man's yoke had been cheated abused and made captives de facto whatever may have been their status de jure."

original: (p.9) He does not agree with the old terms used to describe Indians and Indian related matters.

obfuscation: '' The so-called hostile camp '' ( p.10 ) One thing that is different in this text compared to Walkers , is that there is more interest in the Indians history and their side of the conflict .
